_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Airgas Northeast Charlestown, NH facility, which is owned and operated by Airgas USA, LLC, is located at 806 River Road, Charlestown, NH. Management and employees at the Charlestown facility are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of covered chemicals including propane. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with local emergency response personnel to mitigate the release and minimize the impact of the release to the community and the environment.



The facilities primary operation is the storage, trans-fill and distribution of propane cylinders. Propane is trans-filled from a bulk storage tank to portable cylinders, and cylinders are stored and staged for transportation.



The worst-case and alternative release scenario reports can be viewed at the facility and were prepared using RMP*Comp. Mitigation systems are in place throughout the process system. These reduce the likelihood of a release and are also designed to reduce the magnitude of release should it occur. The mitigation methods include check valves, pressure relief devices, vents, grounding equipment, purge systems and written maintenance and operating procedures. 



The facility has developed a comprehensive plan compliant with EPA's Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR 68) designed to prevent accidental releases of propane. The program utilizes technology, sound engineering practices, administrative controls and active employee participation.



Employees are frequently consulted concerning various aspects of the program and process and are asked to provide input regarding safety and operational improvement.



Written process safety information was developed for the propane system to enable managers, supervisors and employees to identify and understand the process hazards. This information was utilized to conduct a PHA which assists management and employees in making decisions for improving safety and reducing the consequences of a pro

pane release. The PHA focuses attention on equipment, instrumentation, utilities, human actions (routine and non-routine), and external factors that might impact the process by identifying potential failure points or failure modes in the process. The PHA will be updated every 5 years.



Detailed operating procedures exist which describe tasks to be performed, operating conditions to be maintained, and safety and health precautions to be taken. The operating procedures are reviewed periodically and revised as necessary.



Employees are thoroughly trained, including maintenance and contract employees. The training meets the requirements of the OSHA Hazard Communication Standard (29 CFR 1910.1200). The training also includes operating procedures, safe work practices, emergency procedures (including alarms), special assignments, evacuation and emergency response, safety rules and procedures, routine and non-routine work authorization, and other pertinent process safety information. Training is provided to employees by traditional classroom and hands-on methods. Demonstrations, observations and written tests are used to evaluate employee understanding.



A contractor screening process is in place to ensure contract employees hired to perform work can accomplish their assigned tasks without compromising the safety and integrity of the covered process. The contractor program includes review of contractor safety qualifications and knowledge of the work being performed. 



Pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR) are used with new or modified processes to improve the design and construction of the process from a reliability, quality and safety standpoint. PSSR recommendations are resolved prior to final installation or process start up. Items completed prior to the initial process start up include piping and instrumentation diagrams, operating procedures and initial employee training. 



An on-going mechanical integrity program (maintenance) is used to ensure safe process oper

ations. Equipment used to store or handle propane has been designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the potential for a release. The maintenance program includes the required inspections/tests, the appropriate frequency, written procedures, and training of maintenance personnel, documentation of results and documentation of manufacturer recommendations to prevent failure of equipment and instrumentation.



Hazardous and non-routine work is controlled in a consistent manner. The hazards identified are communicated to all affected employees and appropriate control measures are taken to prevent an accidental release. The program references and requires lock out/tag out, hot work, elevated work, line breaking and appropriate authorizations.



Management of Change (MOC) procedures have been developed to review proposed changes to the covered process. MOC procedures include changes to equipment, processes or procedures that are not considered "replacement in kind."



Process incidents that result in or could have resulted in a release are investigated and documented. The purpose of the incident investigation process is to ensure appropriate and adequate corrective actions are implemented to prevent a re-occurrence of similar incidents. Process incidents are investigated by a team that consists of management personnel as well as knowledgeable employees. All resolutions are communicated to affected employees.



The facility has an emergency preparedness/response plan. The plan outlines what actions employees are to take when there is a release of propane. The plan complies with OSHA's Emergency Action Plan standard (29 CFR 1910.38) and has been coordinated with local emergency response personnel.



The facility receives an internal compliance audit at least once every 3 years. The audit includes an evaluation of the design and effectiveness of the risk management system. An audit tool is used to conduct the audit, document deficiencies and track stat

us of identified action items. A procedure is in place to ensure appropriate follow-up. Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.
